title: 107_hr3048
content: The Act may be cited as the "Russian River Land Act" and includes findings and purposes. The Russian River Land Act acknowledges the significance of archaeological and fisheries resources at the confluence of the Russian River and Kenai River. Cook Inlet Region, Inc., an Alaska Native Regional Corporation, has selected lands in the area for their historical and cemetery values. The United States Bureau of Land Management is still adjudicating Cook Inlet Region, Inc.'s selections under ANCSA. The Bureau of Indian Affairs has certified some of the selections as containing cultural artifacts. Part of the selections lie within Chugach National Forest, administered by the United States Forest Service. The Kenai National Wildlife Refuge, managed by the US Fish and Wildlife Service, contains areas eligible for the National Register of Historic Places. Disputes exist between the Forest Service, Fish and Wildlife Service, and Cook Inlet Region, Inc. regarding selections under ANCSA. Legislation is required to ratify an agreement between the Forest Service, Fish and Wildlife Service, and Cook Inlet Region, Inc. to protect and preserve historic, cultural, and natural resources, resolve disputes, and manage public use in the Sqilantnu Archaeological District. The purpose of this Act is to ratify an agreement between the Department of Agriculture, the Department of the Interior, and Cook Inlet Region, Inc. Ratification of agreement between the United States Forest Service, United States Fish and Wildlife Service, and Cook Inlet Region, Inc. The Agreement between Cook Inlet Region, Inc., the United States Department of Agriculture, and the United States Department of the Interior, signed on July 26, 2001, is ratified as a matter of Federal law. Section 5 of the Agreement is subject to conditions including consultation with interested parties by the Fish and Wildlife Service and submission of reports by the Secretary of the Interior. The Agreement between Cook Inlet Region, Inc., the USDA, and the DOI is ratified as federal law. The Secretary of the Interior must submit the exchange agreement to relevant committees before it takes effect. The terms of the Agreement take precedence over conflicting laws. The Secretaries of Agriculture and the Interior are authorized to carry out actions as required by the Agreement. Authorization of $13,800,000 for Cook Inlet Region, Inc. for planning, design, and construction of visitor centers and research facilities. Limitation on fund use for reimbursement of assisting agencies.
